justifications: I am bitterly disappointed by the Brexit decision-it was a dark day for U.K. science.

The Brexit vote has shocked me, and from the reactions I hear at the conference I am attending, it is creating a lot of confusion and uncertainty among the British and to a lesser extent the European scientific community.
If U.K. science falters, neurodegenerative research across the continent may suffer as well.
Some worry about the future viability of projects that depend on international consortia.
This setback comes at a time when a growing emphasis on large multinational initiatives has begun to propel neurodegenerative research forward.
I am bitterly disappointed by the Brexit decision-it was a dark day for U.K. science.

The Brexit vote has shocked me, and from the reactions I hear at the conference I am attending, it is creating a lot of confusion and uncertainty among the British and to a lesser extent the European scientific community.
The U.K. runs the risk of sending a message that it is not a credible international partner for scientific collaboration.
The outcome of last week's referendum cannot be good for scientific research, which is international and must remain so.
Although the U.K. is an island, science is exactly the opposite. We need collaborations to move it forward.
